overview:
## Overview

The exact meaning of “copy” can vary from class to class, but a copy must be a functionally independent object with values identical to the original at the time the copy was made. A copy produced with [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying] is implicitly retained by the sender, who is responsible for releasing it.

[doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying] declares one method, [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying/copy(with:)], but copying is commonly invoked with the convenience method [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObject-swift.class/copy()]. The [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObject-swift.class/copy()] method is defined for all objects inheriting from [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObject-swift.class] and simply invokes [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying/copy(with:)] with the default zone.

Your options for implementing this protocol are as follows:

If a subclass inherits [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying] from its superclass and declares additional instance variables, the subclass has to override [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying/copy(with:)] to properly handle its own instance variables, invoking the superclass’s implementation first.
rawMarkdown:
---
source: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/foundation/nscopying
crawled: 2025-12-05T04:20:06Z
---

# NSCopying

**Protocol**

A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.

## Declaration

```swift
protocol NSCopying
```

## Overview

The exact meaning of “copy” can vary from class to class, but a copy must be a functionally independent object with values identical to the original at the time the copy was made. A copy produced with [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying] is implicitly retained by the sender, who is responsible for releasing it.

[doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying] declares one method, [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying/copy(with:)], but copying is commonly invoked with the convenience method [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObject-swift.class/copy()]. The [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObject-swift.class/copy()] method is defined for all objects inheriting from [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObject-swift.class] and simply invokes [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying/copy(with:)] with the default zone.

Your options for implementing this protocol are as follows:

- Implement [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying] using [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/ObjectiveC/NSObject-swift.class/alloc] and `init...` in classes that don’t inherit [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying/copy(with:)].
- Implement [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying] by invoking the superclass’s [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying/copy(with:)] when `NSCopying` behavior is inherited. If the superclass implementation might use the [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopyObject] function, make explicit assignments to pointer instance variables for retained objects.
- Implement [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying] by retaining the original instead of creating a new copy when the class and its contents are immutable.

If a subclass inherits [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying] from its superclass and declares additional instance variables, the subclass has to override [doc://com.apple.foundation/documentation/Foundation/NSCopying/copy(with:)] to properly handle its own instance variables, invoking the superclass’s implementation first.

## Copying

- **copy(with:)**: Returns a new instance that’s a copy of the receiver.

## Copying

- **NSMutableCopying**: A protocol that mutable objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
